title_oics: African Group of Negotiators submissions play significant role in achieving the Koronivia Joint Work on Agriculture
title_project: RPL EA: Regional and national engagement, synthesis and strategic research
scope_comments: AGN submissions focused on articulating a common African position on Agriculture, and influence the global decision on agriculture.
outcome_impact_statement: The African Group of Negotiators (AGN) submissions significantly contributed to Koronivia Joint Work on Agriculture at COP23. Since 2012, CCAFS East Africa has continuously supported agriculture and climate change negotiators and experts from Africa to prepare submissions for UNFCCC negotiations. More recently, the roadmap developed during SBSTA48 builds heavily on AGN submission. Over 10 technical working sessions have been convened with AGN, where CCAFS and CGIAR knowledge outputs provided scientific evidence to articulate vulnerability of African agriculture to climate change.

title_oics: The use of WEAI in the AU’s agricultural programme framework and prospects for promoting WEAI in national surveys across Africa
title_project: 6.1.1 Women's Empowerment in Agriculture: Access to and Control over Resources
scope_comments: Sub-Saharan Africa
outcome_impact_statement: The African Union’s Malabo/CAADP biennial reporting framework and guidelines in 2017 recommended the use of the WEAI. Indicator 4.4, “Proportion of rural women that are empowered in agriculture”, was calculated using the WEAI’s five domains of empowerment (5DE) method. This will help us scale-up the WEAI and integrate it into national-level surveys across African countries.

title_oics: Application of Monitoring and Evaluation for Land in Africa (MELA) Framework in 12 African Countries
title_project: 5.1.1 Enhancing Tenure Security
scope_comments: Process is still being rolled out in some countries
outcome_impact_statement: PIM researchers worked with African Land Policy Centre to develop a Monitoring and Evaluation framework for assessing progress on land governance in Africa.  The MELA framework is being piloted by 12 countries in Africa.  This allows tracking of progress on commitments made under the AU Declaration on Land Governance in Africa, including commitments to land rights for women and special groups, e.g. pastoralists.

title_oics: Aflasafe products protect maize and groundnut from aflatoxin contamination in more than 100,000 hectares in four countries in sub-Saharan Africa
title_project: Technological and institutional innovations for assessing and mitigating food safety risks related to aflatoxins designed and tested, including capacity building
scope_comments: Large-scale use of Aflasafe is expanding to Burkina Faso, Tanzania, Ghana, Zambia, Malawi, Mozambique, and is expected to occur in other countries across Sub-Saharan Africa (e.g. Mali, Zimbabwe, Cameroon, Ethiopia).
outcome_impact_statement: IITA is implementing strategic partnerships with private companies or Government entities to use Aflasafe products in maize and groundnut fields of four sub-Saharan Africa nations. Over 100,000 ha were treated with Aflasafe during 2017, allowing production of maize and groundnut with safe aflatoxin levels. Large-scale use of Aflasafe contributed to improve food safety [e.g. in Nigeria 91% of samples had less than 20 ppb] and increased the income of smallholder maize farmers (average 11.5% more than regular maize).

title_oics: Joint Village Land Use Planning methodology secures tenure for pastoralist women in Tanzania
title_project: 5.1.1 Enhancing Tenure Security
outcome_impact_statement: The Sustainable Rangelands Management Project Project introduced participatory rangeland resource mapping, based on experiences in Ethiopia, to the Village Land Use Planning (VLUP) in Tanzania.   Working with the National Land Use Planning Commission (NLUPC), the project was able to secure resources across village boundaries and group Certificates of Customary Right of Occupancy that secured rights to shared grazing area of 12,187 ha, benefitting more than 3000 pastoralists/ agro-pastoralists, and incorporation of this approach in the NLUPC Guidelines.

title_oics: CCAFS evidence on scalable CSA business models drove USD 170million national policy investment in India to curb crop residue burning
title_project: Developing, adapting and targeting portfolios of CSA practices for sustainable intensification of smallholder and vulnerable farming systems in South Asia
scope_comments: Areas encircling residue burning affected zones showcase intense levels of health & productivity losses. Major high risk areas targeted are Haryana, Punjab& Delhi-NCR affected due to immense rice residue burning.
outcome_impact_statement: Science-based evidence generated by CCAFS-CIMMYT & partners in the CSVs helped the Indian Government to prioritize crop residues management solutions and establish a large scale routing investment of INR 1150 crores for in-situ management using the Happy Seeder technology. Responding the Prime Ministers call to curb to crop residue burning while providing sustainable and scalable solutions, this scheme targets an increased incomes for over 2 million farmers, improving soil health, reducing water use and carbon footprints in 4 million hectares.

title_oics: Agriculture negotiators reach agreement at COP23
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP3: Engagement, synthesis and support
scope_comments: The Koronivia Joint Work on Agriculture was agreed upon by all countries that are party to the UNFCCC.
outcome_impact_statement: CCAFS’s research and engagement were instrumental in supporting the UNFCCC COP23 decision on the Koronivia Joint Work on Agriculture. CCAFS provided scientific evidence on the importance of agriculture to the Paris Agreement goals, analysis of mitigation and adaptation in the NDCs, and concrete technical and policy options for addressing agriculture in UNFCCC negotiations, and convened workshops that negotiators cited as critical to enabling them to formulate their positions and come to an agreement.

title_oics: 10 farmers’ organizations and public institutions in LAM empowered with tools to identify CSA options in line with seasonal forecasts
title_project: Putting climate into extension services: Climate-Site-Specific Management Systems (CSMS) for grounding climate smart agriculture to farm rice systems
outcome_impact_statement: 10 farmer organizations in 6 counties in LAM now have fully dedicated agro-climatic prediction and climate-site-specific agronomy analysis teams, sustainably producing climate-site-specific agronomic recommendations and seasonal agro-climatic forecasts in connection with national meteorological services. Two farmer organizations in Colombia adopted novel agro-climatic prediction practices; two national meteorological services strengthen their seasonal prediction capacity by automating the Climate Predictability Tool (CPT); 6 organizations use climate-site-specific agronomy to identify best CSA options.

title_oics: African meteorological institutions provide new high-resolution seasonal climate analyses for agricultural decision-making across 5 countries and regionally
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP4: Engagement, synthesis and support
scope_comments: Also includes IGAD and ECOWAS regions, through regional climate centers.
outcome_impact_statement: Five National Meteorological Services serving a rural population of 125 million, and two regional climate centers, in Africa routinely provide new high-resolution information and analyses of growing season characteristics for agricultural and food security decision-makers.  The process has elevated the capacity and status of collaborating NMS.  CCAFS developed the new tools, and contributed to their implementation and capacity development in partnership with the IRI's ENACTS (Enhancing National Climate Services) initiative.

title_oics: Informing decisions making on investments in agricultural research, resource management, and infrastructure through engagement with USAID
title_project: 1.1.2 Improved Quantitative Strategic Foresight Modeling Tools and Applications
scope_comments: The interaction per se took place in Washington DC, with the potential to inform USAID's global mission.
outcome_impact_statement:
In 2017 IFPRI published a report on the use of Quantitative Foresight Modeling to inform the CGIAR Research Portfolio. The study, led by EPTD in collaboration with CGIAR and external partners, was originally commissioned and funded by the United States Agency for International Development (USAID).
After completion, USAID showed an interest in using the results of the analysis to inform the strategic thinking of the USAID Bureau on Food Security (BFS) on questions related to investments toward poverty reduction.

title_oics: ASTI data inform policies to improve agricultural research capacity, efficiency, and output delivery in Swaziland (Kingdom of Eswatini)
title_project: 1.2.3 Decision Support Systems for R&D
outcome_impact_statement: ASTI data contributed to a policy that prioritized higher education training for agricultural researchers in Swaziland (The Kingdom of Eswatini), and was used in presentations, posters, and meeting communications to advocate for a reform of the national agricultural research system which is expected to improve research funding, the recruitment and advancement of qualified researchers, and research output delivery.

title_oics: More than 100 000 farmers increased their productivity based on climate-site-specific agronomy recommendations in LAM
title_project: Putting climate into extension services: Climate-Site-Specific Management Systems (CSMS) for grounding climate smart agriculture to farm rice systems
outcome_impact_statement: About 100 000 farmers in Colombia benefit from climate-site-specific-agronomy-analysis generated by CIAT and Partners . Fedearroz and Fenalce adjusts their blanket recommendation systems with site-specific CSA practices identified by analysis. The former increased 15% its production and reduces 18 % of costs; benefiting 3000 farmers; Fenalce increased 24% its yields and benefit 3335 famers. The- Secretary-of-Agriculture-and-Rural-Development-Pereira used the analysis to identify 119 groups of agroecological-zones within 55923 hectares benefiting 90000 farmers. In Mexico, through MasAgro 4000 farmers access to data-driven-CSA-practices.

title_oics: Scaling out Solar Pump Irrigators’ Cooperate Enterprise (SPICE) model in India
title_project: [Regional Program Leader] SA: Scaling up/out Climate-Smart Agriculture Technologies, Practices and Services across South Asia
outcome_impact_statement: The Solar Pump Irrigators’ Cooperate Enterprise (SPICE) tested and evaluated in the states of Gujarat and Bihar in India by IWMI and CCAFS in collaboration with Tata Trust is being scaled out by the Government of India through a new multi-billion-dollar scheme to implement solarisation of farm irrigation. As per the scheme, the Government of India, Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (MNRE) plan to provide 2.75 million solar pumps to the individual farmers or/and farmers’ cooperatives across India.

title_oics: Livestock Master Plan guides public and private investments in Ethiopia to lift more than 2 million households out of poverty
title_project: Activity 5.1.3 Policy Identification and generation
scope_comments: A similar process has started in Tanzania, Rwanda and Bihar (India)
outcome_impact_statement: Livestock researchers and partners used their modelling expertise to provide a guide for public and private investments in Ethiopia, with the objective of reducing poverty; achieving food and nutritional security; contributing to economic growth, exports and foreign exchange earnings; and contributing to climate mitigation and adaptation. This roadmap, or master plan, was then used by various actors including the World Bank to shape their investments, which will ultimately impact more than 2.3 million of Ethiopia’s 11 million livestock-keeping households.

title_oics: Creating and supporting SME opportunities in the pork value chain in Uganda
title_project: Activity 2.2.1 Development and evaluation of herd health packages
scope_comments: Trainings through our SMEs have expanded to Kenya, Nigeria and Tanzania.
outcome_impact_statement: The Livestock CRP generated evidence on gaps and opportunities in the pork value chain through assessments leading to intervention tests, at both farm and market levels. The work, started under Livestock & Fish, also established multi-stakeholder platforms, providing business and networking opportunities and agribusiness linkages to emerging SMEs run by farmers and young entrepreneurs. This capacity development has expanded their horizons and provided business opportunities in training, selling feeds, providing pig AI services and trading in pork.

title_oics: Bundling of animal health services increases access to quality services to more than 90% of pastoralists
title_project: Activity 2.4.1 Animal Health Service provision
outcome_impact_statement: Access to animal health services is one of the most important factors in improving livestock productivity.  We piloted bundling of additional services by public and private sectors during vaccination campaigns. In two counties in Kenya, Garissa and Marsabit, it's now routine for the government to invite private sector actors to provide additional services while the government provides vaccinations. This has saved the government money, increased business opportunities for the private sector, and provided quality services to pastoralists at affordable prices.

title_oics: World Food Programme uses mobile-based monitoring tools to guide programming in three countries, affecting up to 2.6 m persons
title_project: (GLO-EA-WA- ICRAF) Partnerships for scaling climate-smart agriculture (P4S-CSA)
scope_comments: Initial countries are Niger, Afghanistan and DRC but WFP is looking to scale the innovation globally.
outcome_impact_statement: ICRAF, with WFP, validated using voice-calls over mobile phones to collect nutrition information from women and mothers. The immediate user of this innovation is the WFP's Vulnerability, Assessment and Mapping Unit who provide technical support across WFP and help monitor and trigger responses. Based on the research and engagement, WFP is piloting the use this innovation in three countries, where they serve 2.6 million beneficiaries, and created a training module based on the innovation for further dissemination and scaling.

title_oics: The Kenya Livestock Insurance Program (KLIP) improved drought mitigation and enhanced food security for over 20,000 pastoralist households in 2017.
title_project: Activity 4.3.2 Policy advice on environmental issues
outcome_impact_statement: KLIP, a Government of Kenya funded drought insurance program, paid out Kshs. 494 million to 22,000 vulnerable pastoralist households in 2017 alone . These pay-outs ensured that farmers could buy their own food as well as fodder, drugs and water for their livestock during periods of drought. Covering eight counties in Kenya, the program has enabled the beneficiaries to keep their animals alive after the failure of the short and long rains in 2016 and 2017.

title_oics: Implementing the ITPGRFA in Bhutan, Burkina Faso, Costa Rica, Côte d’Ivoire, Guatemala, Nepal, Rwanda and Uganda: highlights
title_project: Global policy support for biologically diverse, climate resilient agriculture
scope_comments: Other countries that benefitted from the experiences in the eight GRPI project countries listed above include Benin, India, Madagascar, Malaysia, Zambia, Zimbabwe.
outcome_impact_statement: With technical support of Bioversity International, government organizations in eight countries developed policies/laws, introduced these into national policy processes to create policy/legal space for Treaty implementation, identified genetic resources within their country to be included in the multilateral system,  designated national competent authorities capable to consider requests for access to plant genetic resources for food and agriculture and sharing of those resources with users worldwide. The eight countries are implementing the Treaty and Nagoya Protocol in a mutually supportive way.

title_oics: Rwanda’s national agricultural extension service facilitates 75,000 Rwandan farmers to access, understand and use climate services through participatory processes
title_project: Climate Services for Agriculture: Empowering Farmers to Manage Risk and Adapt to a Changing Climate in Rwanda
outcome_impact_statement: The Rwanda Climate Services for Agriculture project supported the Twigire Muhinzi agricultural extension service to scale up the Participatory Integrated Climate Services for Agriculture (PICSA) process in 20 of Rwanda’s 30 districts.  A thousand trained government staff and volunteer Farmer Promoters trained and facilitated 75,000 Rwandan farmers to understand climate information and incorporate it into their decisionmaking.  Initial M&E results show that >85% of participating farmers change their farm or livelihood management in response, and share the information with peers.

title_oics: 196 institutions in Honduras, Colombia, Guatemala and Nicaragua have adopted Local-Technical Agroclimatic-Committees (LTACs) approach as a mechanism to reduce agroclimatic-risks
title_project: [Regional Program Leader] LAM: Local to National/Regional synthesis, research and engagement
scope_comments:
Mapping the following sub-IDOS: 
1. Increased capacity for innovation in partner development organizations and in poor and vulnerable communities 
2. Enhanced capacity to deal with climactic risks and extremes
outcome_impact_statement: Regional south-south exchanges and continuous engagement for scaling-out the CCAFS-LTAC approach with institutions in Honduras(90), Colombia(80), Guatemala(18), and Nicaragua(8) have led to the creation of 13 new LTACs and strengthening of 5 existing LTACs across the four countries. The initiative has enabled the empowerment of more than 190 institutions including farmer-organizations, private-sector, international-NGOs, and governmental-organizations, through new capacities related to participatory generation, provision, interpretation and use of forecast-based recommendations for adaptation to climate variability led by CIAT’s modelling-team.

title_oics: Cauca leads climate smartness for agriculture in Colombia
title_project: [Regional Program Leader] LAM: Local to National/Regional synthesis, research and engagement
scope_comments: The Cauca CSV in Colombia is now known in other countries (Caribbean countries, Honduras, Chile, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, El Salvador, Guatemala) through the south-south exchanges that have been carried out.
outcome_impact_statement: Municipal and State authorities in Cauca are promoting and investing in CSA practices aiming to reach approximately 150.000 farmers, as a result of the implementation of the CSV approach, using evidence generation and local empowerment. In addition, the State Government of Cauca approved USD$66 million from the Royalties National Fund to give to CRC (Cauca Environmental Authority) to scale CSA in at least 8 municipalities of the State.

title_oics: The evaluation of Egypt’s cash transfers program contributed to the decision to continue the program and influenced approaches to targeting.
title_project: 4.1.2 Improving Design and Delivery of Social protection for Nutrition and Other Outcomes
outcome_impact_statement: IFPRI’s comprehensive impact evaluation of Egypt’s cash transfer program for Government of Egypt’s (GOE) Ministry of Social Solidarity (MOSS), with funding from the World Bank, contributed to the policy dialogue about the program between MOSS, the Ministry of Finance, the President’s office and the World Bank. Lessons from the evaluation contributed to the GOE decision to continue funding the program and to the World Bank decision to continue co-financing it. MOSS indicated using the study findings to improve targeting.

title_oics: Use of tricot crowdsourced citizen science approach for variety trials increases access/availability of adapted seeds for 1.3 million Ethiopian farmers
title_project: (SA-BIOVERSITY) Outscaling a citizen science approach to test climate adaptation options on farms
outcome_impact_statement: The main innovation the use of the tricot crowdsourced citizen science approach for variety trials, which is a cost-effective way to massively test new climate-stress tolerant and nutritious crop varieties directly on farm, generating information about local adaptation/acceptability and disseminating the seeds in one go. ISSD-Ethiopia adopted this approach in its large-scale seed sector development programme and used the approach with 5,995 farmers, who subsequently shared seeds with others and created seed demand, affecting an estimated 1.3 million farmers.

title_oics: Mechanization & Policies for Labor Saving Technology Research reduces tractor market imperfection and increases knowledge exchange in Ghana and Ethiopia
title_project: 2.1.2 Mechanization and Policies for Labor Saving Technology
outcome_impact_statement: Tractor spare parts and attachments are now imported into Ghana and tractor buyers are trained by servicing professionals on the proper usage of tractors due to research on the efficacy of Agricultural Mechanization Services Enterprise Centers (AMSECs) that found the availability of spare parts and other equipment were lacking and tractor breakdowns were a result of improper usage. The promotion of South-South Learning led to the formation of ?mechanization forums? for the frequent exchange of information between Ethiopia and Nepal.

title_oics: Supporting Nepal’s Federal Transition through research and engagement on the devolution of the agricultural sector.
title_project: 2.3.2 Public Sector Reforms to Improve Agricultural Policy Processes
outcome_impact_statement: A study demanded by Nepal’s Ministry of Agricultural Development (MoAD) analysed how agriculture has been devolved in other federal or quasi-federal settings and generated primary data on the concerns of district-level agricultural service providers and rural households in Nepal. Through repeated engagement with high-level policymakers, MoAD adopted suggestions in the study on food technology and quality control and the structure of agricultural training centers. Moreover, MoAD accepted Kenya as a model for devolution and undertook a study tour there.

title_oics: The use and influence of structural transformation research by policymakers, development agencies and academics.
title_project: 2.1.3 Rural Entrepreneurship and Nonfarm Business Promotion
outcome_impact_statement: Research conducted on Structural Transformation (ST) has had a significant global influence with policymakers, development agencies and academics. The work has appeared in a DFID Economic Development Strategy,  AGRA’s 2017 Africa Agriculture Status Report, in a series of UNECA country profiles, and in the Economist and Monthly Digest of the National Bureau of Economic Research. The work was selected by ODI as an impact case study at the request of DFID, which concludes that it had significant policy impact.

title_oics: Research on Ethiopia’s health insurance and safety net programs results in more inclusive integrated programs for the poor
title_project: 4.1.2 Improving Design and Delivery of Social protection for Nutrition and Other Outcomes
scope_comments: N/A
outcome_impact_statement: The Ethiopian Government and Development Agencies moved toward the development of more inclusive integrated programs around the Community Based Health Insurance (CBHI) and Productive Safety Net Program (PSNP) in Ethiopia as a result of research conducted under the Ethiopia Strategy Support Program that found that many PSNP beneficiaries were not enrolled in the CBHI, leaving their food security vulnerable to sudden illness, and despite their level of poverty, beneficiaries that were enrolled were not receiving a premium waiver.

title_oics: Impact on the trade negotiations between the European Union and two African Regional Economic Communities
title_project: 3.1.1 Impact of Agricultural Policies and Incentives along the Value Chains
outcome_impact_statement: The trade relations between African countries and the European Union have high stakes for both regions. The negotiations of the Economic Partnership Agreements have remained a sensitive agenda since 2007. PIM modelling capacity has provided independent quantifications of the agreements. The research outputs have been at the core of the official impact assessment to the policy makers. The current policy outcomes are consistent with the results provided and contrast the outcomes of trade agreements on development and food security.

title_oics: Collaborating for Resilience(CoRe) approach is used to build effective coalitions of civil society and government agencies for pro-poor land governance.
title_project: 5.2.1 Governing Shared Landscapes
outcome_impact_statement: Collaborating for Resilience(CoRe) approach, provides a structured framework for understanding stakeholder interactions and organizing for social and institutional change. The International Land Coalition is applying this framework to increase the effectiveness of their National Engagement Strategies (NES), which are coalitions of civil society and government agencies for pro-poor land governance.  Comparative analysis of experiences using the CoRe framework helps guide decisions on when and how best to engage government in the work of the multi-stakeholder platforms for land tenure reform.

title_oics: Ethiopia adopts WLE research findings to improve the returns on its massive investments in soil and water management
title_project: Synthesis of land restoration successes and failures with a special focus on Ethiopia
outcome_impact_statement: In 2017, the Prime Minister approved a policy to make all agricultural water technologies tax exempt. Ethiopia also adopted a new Soils Strategy to target soil fertility management interventions in various landscape niches; and the Sustainable Land Management Program (SLMP) began adopting new implementation interventions that target interventions at different landscape levels following community-led processes. These outcomes are a direct result of WLE research, capacity strengthening and policy engagement. Together, they can greatly enhance the impacts of agricultural investments.

title_oics: Evidence-based soils agronomy for raising crop production in Africa
title_project: Land Restoration Planning and Performance Management
scope_comments: The speed and low cost of light-based soil-plant diagnostic tools allow soil and plant analysis to be applied and assessed at national scale (Continent level mapping in 14 African countries).
outcome_impact_statement: A growing suite of innovative low-cost decision-support tools and soil datasets produced by ICRAF and its partners through the  Africa Soil Information Service (AfSIS) and are being used by 14 African governments and other investors to map soil properties and measure crop nutritional responses to different soil management regimes.  These technologies are guiding the sustainable restoration of degraded lands and have results in the development of several state-of-the-art national soil information systems (in Ethiopia, Ghana, Nigeria, and Tanzania).

title_oics: Sri Lankan sanitation policy adopts recycling of septage for reuse as fertilizer
title_project: Support of RRR business development, implementation and scaling-up
scope_comments: As the results from IWMI's research on recycling and reuse of human waste is leading to an increase in requests for assistance from more countries.
outcome_impact_statement: With WLE support, IWMI has played a highly influential role in preparing the 2017 Sri Lanka Sanitation Policy. IWMI developed the section on septage management including options for resource recovery and reuse of waste.  96% of all Sri Lankan households have septic tanks or latrines. These pose a significant environmental and health hazard if not appropriately treated.  Reuse and recovery, when rolled out, will reduce these hazards as well as produce valuable recycled products such as organic fertilizer.

title_oics: Stakeholders use A4NH evidence from program evaluations to inform decisions that guide and support nutrition-sensitive programming and policies in Ethiopia
title_project: Engagement with key stakeholders in design, implementation and evaluation of nutrition-sensitive agricultural policies
outcome_impact_statement: Policymakers in Ethiopia, informed by evidence from Transform Nutrition, a program funded by DFID and A4NH, were guided to redesign the Productive Safety Net Programme with the inclusion of specific nutrition elements to increase the potential for this program to improve maternal and child nutrition.

title_oics: Donors use evidence to inform their investment strategies that guide and support nutrition-sensitive programming and policies in West Africa
title_project: Evidence on enabling environments, effective decision making processes and impacts of nutrition-sensitive agricultural policies
scope_comments: Burkina Faso, Ghana, Nigeria, and Senegal  are focal countries for Transform Nutrition - West Africa
outcome_impact_statement: Recognizing the wide influence of Transform Nutrition, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation invested $4 million to launch the three-and-a-half-year Transform Nutrition West Africa initiative for nutrition knowledge generation and mobilization across the region

title_oics: Global nutrition leaders have applied learning from the Transforming Nutrition course in their work as program practitioners and policy makers
title_project: Capacity strengthening and leadership development for nutrition-sensitive agricultural policy and programming
scope_comments: It is likely outcomes have occurred and will continue to occur in more countries and at regional and global levels where participants have influence in program, policy, and funding decisions.
outcome_impact_statement: Participants in the innovative ‘Transforming Nutrition: Ideas, Policies and Outcomes’ course have applied the knowledge and evidence they gained from the course to specific national and sub-national situations in their home countries to identify strategic areas for nutrition action. The curriculum, designed and taught by the Institute for Development Studies (IDS) and researchers from IFPRI incorporates evidence from, among others, CGIAR research and engagement around both nutrition-sensitive and nutrition-specific actions.

title_oics: BAMTAARE SA, the first private company licensed to manufacture and distribute Aflasafe SN01 for benefiting Senegal and The Gambia
title_project: Technological and institutional innovations for assessing and mitigating food safety risks related to aflatoxins designed and tested, including capacity building
outcome_impact_statement: A4NH researchers at IITA developed Aflasafe SN01, an aflatoxin biocontol product for use in Senegal and The Gambia, in collaboration with USDA-ARS, and other research and development partners. IITA signed a Technology Transfer and Licensing Agreement with BAMTAARE SA for benefiting groundnut and maize value chains. This is the first license to manufacture and distribute an Aflasafe product granted to a private company in Africa. The agreement contemplates full ownership, operation, and management by BAMTAARE and technical support from IITA.

title_oics: Evidence from Rwanda showed that consumption of iron biofortified beans had a positive effect on cognitive performance of young women
title_project: Evidence on nutritional efficacy and program cost-effectiveness
scope_comments: Even though the study was conducted in Rwanda, the results would hold for any population for whom beans is a staple crop and who suffer from iron deficiency
outcome_impact_statement: Published evidence on the nutritional impact of iron-biofortified crops offers a road map for policymakers to consider. Within the context of an RCT in Rwanda, one group of female college students consumed iron biofortified beans and another group consumed conventional beans. Results showed that the consumption of iron biofortified beans positively affected the cognitive performance of the young women in the treatment group. Iron biofortified beans were developed in close collaboration between HarvestPlus, CIAT and the Rwanda Agricultural Board.

title_oics: Use of A4NH evidence led to improved risk assessment and risk communication benefitting up to 94 million consumers in Vietnam
title_project: Technological and institutional innovations for assessing, communicating and mitigating food safety risks designed and tested, with capacity building (Product Lines)
scope_comments: We have been successful in obtaining a $100,000 grant from USAID to extend to Cambodia and are exploring extending to Bangladesh and Myanmar.
outcome_impact_statement: Vietnam’s food systems are rapidly evolving. Food safety is a high priority for consumers and the government. A4NH scientists contributed to a range of initiatives which have supported a shift in food safety policy and implementation. One of the most effective initiatives was the National Food Safety Risk Assessment Taskforce. Based on a recent assessment report, requested by the government and contributed by the Taskforce and partners, the government committed to implementing measures to improve food safety in the country.

title_oics: Use of Rift Valley fever decision support tools led to improved interventions benefitting an estimated 3.1 million smallholders in Kenya
title_project: Portfolio of validated methods for alternative surveillance and control options of animal and human disease, particularly in higher-risk areas
scope_comments: Tanzania and Uganda, also vulnerable to RVF, have experienced epidemics in the recent past. They are considering risk-based intervention measures to minimize animal and human health impacts during outbreaks.
outcome_impact_statement: ILRI developed and disseminated refined risk maps and a decision support framework for guiding decision-making processes in the prevention and control of Rift Valley fever (RVF). The Department of Veterinary Services in Kenya incorporated these tools into their national RVF contingency plan and also used them to implement risk-based RVF interventions. Improved control of RVF in animals would limit human infections and hence safeguard health and wellbeing of the local communities in 22 counties with high RVF risk in Kenya.

title_oics: Knowledge of brucellosis epidemiology to support the development of a national brucellosis strategy to support 45 million Kenyans
title_project: Portfolio of validated methods for alternative surveillance and control options of animal and human disease, particularly in higher-risk areas
scope_comments: Ethiopia, Tanzania and Uganda will draw on the Kenyan example in developing their own strategic approach to brucellosis control.
outcome_impact_statement: After years of advocacy and integrated field research by CGIAR and other partners, the Government of Kenya prioritized brucellosis as a neglected zoonoses for government attention and a draft National Strategy for Brucellosis was recently finalized. With a national strategy, new combined health and livestock sector policies for brucellosis surveillance and control can be implemented by government administrations, public and private sector hospitals, and NGOs. The result will be better patient management and reduced use of tertiary antibiotics.

title_oics: Analysis and collaboration lays the foundation for food system improvements in Ethiopia
title_project: Methods, metrics and tools for assessing and analyzing diet-food system linkages
outcome_impact_statement: The first step toward identifying ways to improve something is to understand the situation as it currently exists. Guided by this premise, A4NH researchers embarked on an in-depth analysis of food systems in four countries. The first, Ethiopia, served as a case study to refine methods and information sharing. Researchers are building strong partnerships with local stakeholders, laying the foundation for future collaboration that will lead to systemwide improvements that have real impacts for consumers throughout these countries.

title_oics: Stakeholders use A4NH evidence from program evaluations to inform decisions that guide and support nutrition-sensitive programming in Bangladesh
title_project: Engagement with key stakeholders in design, implementation and evaluation of nutrition-sensitive agricultural policies
outcome_impact_statement: Numerous stakeholders – donors, investors, UN agencies, and government ministries – used findings from an IFPRI-led pilot study, the Transfer Modality Research Initiative (TMRI) on integrating across sectors and the role of nutrition behavior change communication (BCC) - to inform the design of nutrition, poverty alleviation, and social protection programs and plans in Bangladesh.

title_oics: Policymakers use A4NH evidence to inform decisions that guide and support nutrition-sensitive strategies in Bangladesh
title_project: Engagement with key stakeholders in design, implementation and evaluation of nutrition-sensitive agricultural policies
outcome_impact_statement: Policymakers in Bangladesh drew on evidence from the Transform Nutrition research program consortium (2011-2017), as well as an assessment of the National Nutrition Service (NNS), to inform the nutrition section of the National Five-Year plan in 2015. This plan is the framework for policy decisions made by the Government of Bangladesh. Since the National Nutrition Service assessment was completed, the Government of Bangladesh have implemented recommendations to strengthen frontline delivery through District Nutrition Officers, with support from UNICEF.

title_oics: Building a theoretical basis and public support for nutrition sensitive value chains
title_project: Methods, metrics and tools for assessing and analyzing diet-food system linkages
scope_comments: Scope is both global in nature and multinational - Malawi, Indonesia, and Nigeria. Work is ongoing in both Malawi and Burkina Faso.
outcome_impact_statement: In Phase I of A4NH, A4NH researchers and partners developed a framework for considering how and whether to invest in nutrition-sensitive value chains. Since then, the conceptual framework has been endorsed by the Global Forum on Food Security and Nutrition and used as basis for their policy document on nutrition sensitive value chains, adapted by several Rome-based agencies and applied within country-specific value chain programs, and embedded in several completed and ongoing evaluations.

title_oics: Multi-sectoral policy platform used effectively to promote best practices and pilot programs around biodiversity in Kenya
title_project: Policy process analysis and policy engagement
scope_comments:
Busia county, Kenya

Potential for impact in other counties in Kenya and Ethiopia, Uganda and Tanzania
outcome_impact_statement: Innovative multi-sectoral policy platforms bring together the environment, agriculture and health sectors, in some countries, for the first time. In Kenya, a multi-disciplinary team of farmer organizations, non-governmental organizations, and national and international government agencies have successfully promoted best practices and pilot programs around biodiversity in Kenya. More specifically, they have helped revive interest in nutritious African leafy vegetables by piloting a food procurement model approach between local producers and schools and health clinics.

title_project: 2.4.3 Support to Ghana Policies

title_oics: impact of improved rice varieties in sub-Saharan Africa
outcome_impact_statement: The adoption of improved rice varieties by farmers in 16 countries in Sub-Saharan Africa, was estimated at 3.5 million ha, including 1.4 million ha for NERICA varieties. Yields increased with 431 kg per hectare with adoption of improved varieties, and with 320 kg per hectare with adoption of NERICA varieties. About 8 million people were lifted out of poverty and 7.2 million people out of food insecurity. Average income also increased from US$ 25 capita–1 to US$ 58 capita–1 for NERICA adopters.

title_oics: Remote sensing-based insurance in Tamil Nadu, India
outcome_impact_statement: RIICE - Satellite technology expedites insurance payouts in India’s crop insurance programme in 2016-17 Samba season

title_oics: Farmers adopt healthy rice seedling practices in Bangladesh
outcome_impact_statement: Awareness-raising activities through a 10-minute instructional video by the CSISA project (Cereal Systems Initiative South Asia) in Bangladesh resulted in 60,000 hectares planted with healthy rice seedlings in 2017, while direct training resulted in an additional 28,300 hectares planted under healthy rice seedling techniques

title_oics: POSHAN contributed to the Government of India’s Three-Year Action Agenda
title_project: Engagement with key stakeholders in design, implementation and evaluation of nutrition-sensitive agricultural policies

title_oics: Adoption of improved potato varieties in Peru by 62% of potato farmers
outcome_impact_statement: Farmers growing improved varieties have benefited from higher yield and marketed a larger share of their output, earning higher incomes than comparable neighbors. Results indicate that the market is a good place to promote the adoption of new varieties.

title_oics: Nigeria and Tanzania promote food basket approach to fight against hidden hunger
outcome_impact_statement: Micronutrient malnutrition or hidden hunger is characterized by chronic deficiency of essential vitamins and minerals such as vitamin A, iron and zinc. Adopting a diversified diet that include vitamin A (yellow) cassava, vitamin A (orange) maize, vitamin A (orange) sweetpotato and high iron beans helps in combating these deficiencies. Nigerian and Tanzanian government are putting in place enabling policy environment and are mobilizing funds to support nutrition-sensitive agricultural plans that will disseminate proven biofortified technologies ready for scaling up.

title_oics: Adoption of improved cassava varieties in Nigeria gives 64% productivity gain
outcome_impact_statement: DNA-fingerprinted adoption data revealed that about 66% of cassava growers adopted improved cassava varieties. Adoption of improved varieties is associated with an 82% increase in yield, this corresponds to 3.1 million households that adopted improved cassava varieties. Considering a poverty line of USD 1.25 per person per day at purchasing power parity, analysis showed that 7.15% of the rural poor cassava producers have escaped poverty due to adoption of improved varieties, representing about 2 million individuals.

title_oics: Making ‘invisible’ woman’s contributions to the value chain ‘visible’ with gender Responsive Tools: RTB Value Chains in Uganda and Ecuador
outcome_impact_statement: In order to improve value chain analysis and development with gender and youth lens, several analytical tools were integrated in the Participatory Market Chain Approach. The testing and validation of these tools have allowed that partners (public and private) use them to improve their value chain interventions in Uganda and Ecuador by promoting women and men participation; and to the development of gender responsive business plans based on strategies and business training implemented by women.

title_oics: A network of more than 270 economically viable decentralized seed multipliers in Kenya, Ethiopia and Malawi has been established and improved farmer access to quality seed potato.
outcome_impact_statement: Seed rapid multiplication technologies were adapted and used by national agricultural research institutes and private enterprises to produce early generation seeds (EGS) of robust, user-preferred varieties. Increased availability of ESG allowed for the development of seed business models based on the development of commercial decentralized seed multipliers (DSM) located near to production areas. Seeds produced using quality foundation material (EGS), or in case of Kenya certified seed, and good agricultural practices were made locally available, in a timely manner and at affordable prices to ware potato farmers.

title_oics: Over 1,100 registered vine multipliers in 14 countries in SSA result in over 0.5 million households reached with improved sweetpotato varieties, mostly orange-fleshed types for nutrition enhancement.
outcome_impact_statement: Decentralized sweetpotato vine multipliers (DVMs), play an important role in fostering access to nutritious OFSP vines, by being located closer to the targeted households.  1,118 DVMs have been registered, contributing to increased access to improved planting materials by vulnerable targeted households.  This resulted in over 500,000 direct and 800,000 indirect beneficiaries (approximately 1.34 million households) with access to improved sweetpotato varieties in 14 countries in SSA in 2017.  Since the launch of the SPHI platform (in 2010), over 4.5 million households have been reached.

title_oics: Young women and men in Congo improve on-farm production and processing of cassava in 10 rural communities.
outcome_impact_statement: IITA-Kalambo Youth Agripreneurs (IKYA) is a cooperative of 32 young women and men in Bukavu, DR Congo, who have improved on-farm production and processing of cassava in 10 rural communities. They are engaged in activities that increase income and reduce poverty in rural households. IKYA provides technical training on Integrated Soil Fertility Management to stakeholders who include NGOs and youth groups that are embarking on developing their own agribusinesses.

title_project: AfricaRice W1/2 contribution to RICE Flagship Project 3
CIRAD W1/2 Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 2
Community management of common pool land resources and conservation of biodiversity at landscape scales
Stakeholder platform management in Ghana and Tanzania
